occurrenceRemarks: This is a very small Photinus species, likely just over 5mm. Flashing started closer to the ground but got higher as the night went on. Eventually there were fireflies flashing high in the cottonwood trees as well. Not sure if they were male or female. Slight synchrony was noticed. Display area was open field, with tall grass and a few scattered shrubs, in the flood plain of the Santa Cruz river. It was bordered on both sides by relatively thick trees.
additionalObservers: Participants of the Invertebrates in Education and Conservation Conference.
habitatRemarks: Cottonwood forest.
flashLocation: Flashes are across the open area, as well as high up in the trees.
maleFlashBehavior: Males give off a quick series of three flashes at intervals of about 5 seconds. They often exhibit slightly vertical flight from the first flash to the third flash.
femaleFlashBehavior: No noticed. Possibly flashing from up in the cottonwood trees.

eventRemarks: Located in a dry stretch of the West Branch of the Santa Cruz River near Mission and Ajo Way behind the Food City store. Scott Cywlik of Tucson photographed P. knulli here in previous years
locality: West Branch of the Santa Cruz River, Mission and Ajo Way, Tucson, Arizona
occurrenceRemarks: Fireflies were sitting in ephemeral vegetation in wash bottom at 3-4 feet in height with short flights (within 10 feet of vegetation).
additionalObservers: Candace Fallon, Anna Walker, Saff Killingsworth, Mary Gilbert
habitatRemarks: This is in a dry sand wash with some ephemeral vegetation and some tree species along the edge (mesquite) surrounded by development.

eventRemarks: Fireflies were seen in a very small area. We expected to see them in other places along the riparian area, but apart from one or two flashes upstream about 15m, all activity was focused within microhabitat/wetland.
occurrenceRemarks: Half an hour before dark and at least 10 minutes before sunset, females started appearing on the vegetation. Males started flashing from the vegetation around sunset. At this time, the flashes appeared yellow, but as it got darker, the flashes continued to appear more green. Males started flying after it got darker. There were likely a couple hundred flashing in a very concentrated area.
habitatRemarks: Microhabitat where fireflies were seen is very specific wetland created adjacent to desert canyon stream, about 10 m downstream of a hot spring. At the time of the observation, stream did not seem to be flowing into wetland, so it is likely spring fed, and the bank is shaped in a way that gathers spring water. There was a large pool that was mostly still, and a few marshy areas where cattails and other wetland plants where coming up. The whole area is enclosed in a thicket of willows. There were no other wetland habitats like this (with cattails) seen as we hiked up Turkey Creek from the Gila River, so it is likely firefly activity is restricted to small areas like this. Surrounding canyon in oak, juniper, pinon woodland. Other vegetation along the stream includes alders, small cottonwoods, and sycamores. The monsoon rains brought high waters to the area last summer, but fireflies do not seem to have been disturbed. They were seen at this location last year (2022) on May 30th and the sighting was reported to Western Firefly Project.
flashLocation: Flashes are mostly concentrated in wetland microhabitat adjacent to stream. There are flashes in the vegetation, as well as given off while males are flying.
maleFlashBehavior: Started flashing in vegetation before starting to fly. Some males continued flashing from vegetation throughout the night. They seemed to fall slightly while they flashed. They do not move very far or very fast, though generally move horizontally. The wetland habitat is quite enclosed, and the stayed within the shrub canopy, so they never flew very high. They also stay semi-lit during the interval between flashes, which makes it easy to follow their trajectory.
femaleFlashBehavior: Single flash at short interval. Females were found on vegetation upon arrival to the microhabitat at 8:19 PM, about ten minutes before the males started flashing.

eventRemarks: Brief stop at known BWW location.
identificationRemarks: Cannot be verified to species without photo and/or more definitive flash/glow pattern description.
occurrenceRemarks: One individual observed flashing while on grass.
habitatRemarks: Cottonwood gallery. Rabbit's foot grass and native spp present.
flashLocation: 1' off ground in grass within a few feet of stream.

eventRemarks: Two flashing fireflies were observed. One was always flying while flashing a few feet off ground, and the other was first observed flashing on grass adjacent to water before it flew out of sight towards Cienega Creek while flashing.
occurrenceRemarks: Fireflies were only observed at a distance. One remained on green riparian grass (or perhaps sedges) within feet of the water until approximately 8:15 PM when it flew a few feet off the ground while flashing toward Cienega Creek and disappeared. Another individual was observed flying a few feet off the ground while flashing for approximately 30 minutes during the survey period. This individual appeared to be scouting over much of the pond and its surrounding riparian vegetation, and it also spend some time flying over more xeric grassland between the Cienega and Cienega Creek.
habitatRemarks: Wetland vegetation within a cattle exclosure including cattails and lush herbaceous vegetation. Typical desert grassland vegetation surrounded the riparian habitat.
flashLocation: Continuous flash pattern whether perched on grass near the water or while flying.

occurrenceRemarks: Approximately 75 flashers. Males were flying just above the sedge vegetation at about 2-3 feet. Flashing very fast and flying very fast but localized.
habitatRemarks: Improved natural spring - pool that was excavated for native fish is approximately 3 meters by 4 meters.  Primary vegetation is sedge with dry hillocks and some standing water.  The site is surrounded by ash, cottonwood, and mesquite trees.
flashLocation: Males were flying just above the sedge vegetation throughout most of the flight time.  A few flew up to about 5 from the ground as the evening wore on.
maleFlashBehavior: Flashes were single and fast.  Flight was localized.  This is a much different flash pattern than observed at this site in June of 2022 which was a more typical slow flying slow flashing Bw.  These "fast flashers" appeared sometime in early July of 2022 and had completed their flight by mid-July.
femaleFlashBehavior: I was unable to capture a female to verify.  I think the females were sitting on the vegetation, flashing slightly slower and fainter.

eventRemarks: There was a very bright and very full moon that rose over the site during the time the fireflies were active.
occurrenceRemarks: MSMN - 023- #1-10 (all males) collected and placed in a tent with a GoPro 360 camera to test for synchronicity per R. Sarfati's protocol and request.  The fireflies were then collected and will be sent to Luiz Silveira for comparison to previous earlier collections of Bw at the Muleshoe Ranch for taxonomy and DNA.   This cohort appears to be smaller in size (8.5-9 mm) in general have less orange or rose pink coloration on the elytra than previous Bw collections, and fly much faster.  The flash pattern is a single flash repeated every .67-1second versus other Bw recorded flashes of a single flash every 2-7 seconds.
habitatRemarks: Improved spring with small pool for native fish (3 m x 4 m). Otherwise a sedge community with some standing water and dryer hillocks. Surrounded by ash, cottonwood, and mesquite trees.
flashLocation: This cohort flashes very low, just above the vegetation. As time progresses a few fly higher and farther, but most remain near the sedge tops.  Previous observations in June of 2022 at this location were more typical of Bw flight patterns, starting low near the vegetation but over time flying higher and farther.  This cohort also flashes much faster that other Bw observations.
maleFlashBehavior: Fast flashing and fast flying.
femaleFlashBehavior: I did not get a good female observation.

eventRemarks: This is the 3rd survey night for 2023.  Flashing was also recorded using GoPro 360 cameras per R. Sarfati's protocol for comparison to recordings collected last year from 15 June - 22 July 2022.  Prototype Meidase Trend cameras were also placed at the site and recorded a photo every 10 seconds beginning at 7:30 pm and ending at 10:00 pm.  The cameras will remain at this location for the next 30 days as a field test.
occurrenceRemarks: This is a paired comparison of bright moonlight (2 July) and no moonlight (4 July) as moonrise occurred after the firefly activity had largely stopped about 9pm.  I noticed not difference in time of first or last flash, behavior, or estimated numbers of flashers. This survey was filmed using GoPro 360 cameras and Meidase prototype Trend cameras, as were the July 1 and 2 surveys.
habitatRemarks: Improved spring with a 3 m x 3 m pool for native fish. Primarily a sedge community with some standing water interspersed with dryer hillocks. Surrounded by trees including cottonwood, ash, and mesquite.
flashLocation: In general just at the top of the sedge community and very localized flashing. A few males flew higher and farther as the night wore on.  There were still one or two fireflies flashing when I ended the survey at 9 pm.  This was also the case July 1 and 2 surveys.
maleFlashBehavior: Fast erratic flight. Fast single flash every .67-1 second (measured using a voice recorder then transcribed).

eventRemarks: Saw three individuals near the parking area and one where the cienega crosses the road. All flashes were on the vegetation; no flying was observed. We had gone to marsh site farther up the road to see activity, but we did not diffinitively see any flashing. We were at the large marsh site from about 8:00pm until 8:40pm. It was the tail end of the activity period by the time we got back to Empire Gulch, so if any were flying, we missed them. Growing degree days for 6/12/23 were 1162. Last year on June 12, 2022, the GGD was 1766. It has been a cold spring!
locality: Las Cienegas National Conservation Area- Empire Gulch
occurrenceRemarks: Only saw four individuals at Empire Gulch. Also surveyed large marsh up the road, but no flashes were observed there. Did not catch and photograph specimen, but this is a known site for Bicellonycha wickershamorum, and that is the only species to be expected there.
habitatRemarks: Cienega with cottonwood overstory within desert mesquite grassland. Wetland plants include willow, cattails, and yerba mansa.
flashLocation: Flashing was restricted to vegetation, so courtship flash pattern was not observed. It may have been too cold for flight by the time we got back to Empire Gulch. They could have been flashing earlier and we just missed them. We started the survey at the large marsh up the road, but did not find any individuals flashing there.
maleFlashBehavior: NA
femaleFlashBehavior: NA

eventRemarks:
Site first surveyed in 2021 (New Site).  
29 July 2021 - Dozens flashing in tree tops and on ground <100 (75) Surveyed right before monsoon storm with active lightning and thunder. No rain during survey but rain after
30/31 July - 2021 - Re-visited with Joe Cicero, verified as P. knulli - Calm night , no storms, fewer flashing perhaps 50
18 August 2021 - Handful of flashes noted on vegetation and flying

3 August 2023 - Atlas Survey completed. Site was dry. No apparent recent rains.
locality: Buenos Aires NWF Arivaca Trail Parking Lot
occurrenceRemarks: Likely about 20 flashing...very desultory flashing.  Fireflies would repeat flash cycle 5-10 times and then stop.  Very intermittent in nature.
habitatRemarks: Primarily mesquite with nearby cottonwoods along Wilbur Wash. Site is at trailhead and refuge info parking lot. Fireflies flashing on all 3 sides of parking lot.
flashLocation: Some were flashing from vegetation both low (within 3 feet of ground) and high (tree tops).  The flash was a triptych rapid flash then a 3-4 second break then the triptych rapid flash again.
maleFlashBehavior: Assuming that males were flying. They would flash for several repetitions then stop.
femaleFlashBehavior: No females were evident

eventRemarks:
Fireflies first noted here 11 July 2020 20-30 estimated
                                           13 July 2020 < 15 at site,  two other small groups of < 10 each flashing down drainage near water on road

14 June 2021 2 flashing, 25 June 15-20, 20 July 5-10 flashes, Water event occurred between 25 June and 20 July dates
13 June 2022 - < 10, Bull Noted in Wetland with extensive use in June.  
29 June 2022 < 10
2023 13 June - Candace Fallon and Anna Walker noted a couple of flashes while returning from the Big Marsh
           14 June - Firefly workshop participants visited - <10 flashing
identificationRemarks: Verified based on flash pattern description, time of night, time of year, location, and habitat. This is a known site for Bicellonycha wickershamorum.
occurrenceRemarks: First flash at 6:45 PM. Low flashes in duff and vegetation streamside. Flashing males got higher as night got darker.
additionalObservers:
Jenny Palmer, Brian Grosart, Lily Staler

Note - Survey data entered by Cheryl Mollohan
habitatRemarks: Riparian area with large amount of emergent vegetation including sedge, spearmint, cattails, under partial cottonwood canopy
flashLocation:
6:45 - 7:23 Flashes from duff and streamside
7:23 - 8:45 Flashes from emergent vegetation and 7-8 feet in air above stream
maleFlashBehavior:
6:45-7:23 Single flash of 1 second repeated every 5-7 seconds
7:23 - 8:15 Single flash 1.5-2 seconds repeated every 6 seconds with various loops and squiggles
femaleFlashBehavior: Steady flash 1-2 seconds long in duff and vegetation, 2-7 seconds apart

additionalObservers: Survey conducted by Hans Huth - entered by Cheryl Mollohan
flashLocation: Along the left bank of an extended channel that's overgrown with lots of cover but clear within the channel
maleFlashBehavior: Non-synchronous - slow traveling a length of about 6 feet during course of single pattern
femaleFlashBehavior: No females identified

locality: Las Cienegas Natural Conservation Area Large Marsh
additionalObservers: Candace Fallon, Saff Killingsworth, Sarina Jepsen, Al LeCount
habitatRemarks: Cattails, some open water, surrounding mature cottonwood and riparian community near Cienega Creek
flashLocation: In and above emergent vegetation.  Above open water in wetland. Along riparian corridor of Cienega Creek.
maleFlashBehavior: Slow flying.

eventRemarks:
This site was first located in 2021.
Filming using GoPro cameras per R. Sarfati protocol for this site 15 June - 28 June, and 15-23 July intermittently.  Typical slow flashers and Bw pattern through 6/28.  Fast flashing and fast flying fireflies noted upon our return in mid-July.  This was our final survey and filming.  It appears primarily slow flashing Bw's again but with a few fast flyers. 

Fireflies MS #1-3 collected here and sent to  Laura Hughes who verified them as Bw and then on to Luiz Silviera for further analysis.
habitatRemarks: Improved spring with open pool.  Primarily sedge/grass community surrounded by ash, mesquite, cottonwood trees. Pool is approximately 2 meters X 4 meters.
flashPatternPeriod: Fast flashers flash 1 every 1.1 - 2.05 seconds. Slow flasher 1 every 4.88 seconds
flashLocation: Flashing just above sedge/grass community

eventRemarks: Started the evening survey at the reservoir are up stream. Did not find fireflies there. GGD for Morenci (higher elevation) 1241.5.
occurrenceRemarks: Very few fireflies present. Found beaver carcass. Put camera traps upstream, but did not see any flashes.
habitatRemarks: Fireflies are in marshy areas adjacent to the stream.
flashLocation: First flash was likely missed, as this was the second site we visited for the night. Flashes are in the riparian vegetation adjacent to the floodplain. They seem to like wet areas outside of main waterway.
maleFlashBehavior: Most males flying along slowly while flashing. One male in a hurry shot across the landscape very quickly.
femaleFlashBehavior: There was flashing from the bushes, though never found one to confirm they were females.

eventRemarks: We were just finishing out our field form and starting to walk back to the vehicles when we saw 2 males flashing.  We can't quite remember color - yellow or green, but it was a single flash.  Kayla was able to capture one of the males.  I will be depositing that specimen with Dr. Joe Cicero August 12, 2023.  I photographed it (dorsal and ventral) the next day.
identificationRemarks: Checks out to be within describable parameters… the aedeagus and the other somatic characters are good for Bwp.
occurrenceRemarks: 2 males were seen at end of survey flying above grasses and lower branches of willow.
areaSearchedInHa: Oak Creek upstream of the Cornville Road bridge, both sides of hte creek approximately 0.1 mile.
habitatRemarks: Mixed deciduous riparian with adjacent uplands of mesquite bosque and semi-desert grassland.
flashLocation: Over streamside vegetation, right at the edge of the water.
maleFlashBehavior: We were so excited we finally saw fireflies, that we weren't certain of the color.  Green or yellow, not orange.

locality: Tumacacori National Historical Park (TNHP) and adjacent sites associated with the SantaCruzRiver (SCR), AZ
numberObservers: dozens of personally hosted patrons, post-public viewings
additionalObservers:
Joe and guests
Julius Schlosburg and guests
areaSearchedInHa: fallow field (31.567664, -111.048382); Orchard (31.569058, -111.049243); 'cul-de-sac'= oblong area just before reaching SCR (31.569506, -111.046005); SCR just east of latter (31.569489, -111.045400); deAnzaTrail 10min S of Santa Gertrudis (31.561629, -111.046816)
habitatRemarks: cottonwood/willow bi-lane and associated mesquite bosque paralleling it.
flashLocation: see below
maleFlashBehavior:
In 1983, Cicero identified three periods in the waxing and waning of the species, Maturation, Climax, and Decline. These notes document the most important observations, i.e., those that summarize Climax activity, which were taken on 18-20 August '23, on the four sites known to have held the highest density in the TNHP area since initiation of observations by T.  Palmer in 1921. 

The orchard and fallow field showed relatively negligible numbers during all three periods, but significantly, at the onset of Maturation, the orchard presented the first emergers of the year indicating that eggs were laid there last year. Emergences must have also occurred elsewhere certainly, but these localities weren't given daily observation as was the orchard during public viewings held by the TNHC staff (17-24 July). 

The cul-de-sac, SCR, and the deAnza trail S of Santa Gertrudis, presented the best behavioral observations of all during the August 18-21 dates and, since the season is nearing its end, are therefore considered Climactic. Each location showed ground-to-ground synchrony, ground-t-o-air synchrony and short-lived, mid (1-2 yards)- to long ( 3-5 yards) distance entrainment. These male-male communications did not consummate in a lek- they did not contract into a well defined arena with coherent flash exchanges as described in Cicero (1983), but they did indicate the potential to do so if only the ff were to settle into optimum surface structure to facilitate such interactions. Tall grass and weeds, rough ground with rocks and fallen branches, moon, Nogales lights, and many other itemizable impediments and suppressing factors were present. There were areas with what is estimated to have optimum structure based on the 1983 arena, such as the northwest corner of the orchard, and the S.Gertrudis site, but for reasons unknown, congregations did not ensue. Next year, 2024, we must marshall our efforts into running experiments designed to foment lek formation so that we can document by video the escapades within.

occurrenceRemarks: P. knulli is widespread throughout the area surveyed, and is present beyond the main survey area. We likely saw 100-200 individuals throughout the greater area. Joe Cicero notes that the population size on this evening appears much lower than what he's observed in previous years.
additionalObservers: Saff Killingsworth, Joe Cicero, Cheryl Mollohan, Larry Buschman, Anna Walker, Tony Palmer, Jenny Palmer
habitatRemarks: Dry wash in a desert canyon. Dominant plants include desert willow, soapberry, and mesquite. Several small grassy glades can be found throughout the wash, which is where the fireflies were displaying.
flashLocation: Some stationary flashes from ground (females?) while males typically flew approximately 6-7 feet along vegetation and roadsides. Some were seen flashing from vegetation.
maleFlashBehavior: Typically a yellow-white triplet flash with a 3-second interval, although single and double flashes were also observed. Some males appeared to hover in place for a moment after flashing. No synchrony or lekking observed, although flashes later in the evening appeared to be approaching synchrony.

occurrenceRemarks: A single Photinus knulli adult female was observed perched on vegetation in the canyon.
additionalObservers: Saff Killingsworth, Anna Walker, Joe Cicero, Larry Buschman

occurrenceRemarks: Saw approximately 10 fireflies flashing, both male and female (individuals were briefly captured and examined to confirm sex).
additionalObservers: Cheryl Mollohan, Anna Walker, and participants of the Firefly Atlas workshop
habitatRemarks: Cienega with cottonwood overstory within desert mesquite grassland. Wetland plants include willow, cattails, and yerba mansa.
flashLocation: All flashing was observed from the ground level (no individuals flying).
maleFlashBehavior: Difficult to discern flash pattern since all flashes were from the ground. It's possible it was too cold for males to take flight.

eventRemarks: Observed 3 fireflies: two on the ground and one flying that went high up into the tree canopy and appeared to perch in the vegetation. No individuals were captured or photographed, but the flash pattern and color indicated B. wickershamorum, and this site is very close to the known type locality for the species. We visited this site earlier in the evening (approx 5:15pm) to scout it out and then returned after dark, after another survey (Green Kingfisher Pond), to see if fireflies were present.
occurrenceRemarks: Observed 3 fireflies: two on the ground and one flying that went high up into the tree canopy and appeared to perch in the vegetation. No individuals were captured or photographed, but the flash pattern and color indicated B. wickershamorum, and this site is very close to the known type locality for the species. We visited this site earlier in the evening (approx 5:15pm) to scout it out and then returned after dark, after another survey (Green Kingfisher Pond), to see if fireflies were present.
habitatRemarks: Lush riparian area with cottonwood canopy.
flashLocation: Two flashes were from the ground near the creek, and the third was flying above the creek, slowly moving higher into the tree canopy.

eventRemarks: Quick stop by this potential firefly site after surveying nearby Rock Corral Canyon.
occurrenceRemarks: Approximately 11-12 flashing individuals observed
flashLocation: Individuals were cruising above the creek, in and out of the trees, occasionally perching in the canopy.

occurrenceRemarks: One male captured. 10.5 mm in length. Flashing from atop watercress within Sonoita Creek. Another observed in the same area as the first and flew from just adjacent to the creek over the creek. Further west, we located another flashing from low vegetation, possibly within the creek. It stopped flashing shortly after we arrived at 9:33
habitatRemarks: Ash, willow, cottonwood overstory, within the creek there is tall watercress on which the fireflies were resting and flashing
flashLocation: Flashing mostly from vegetation, occasionally flying 3-8 feet and flashing.
femaleFlashBehavior: Did not observe

eventRemarks: Walked the trails at the Patagonia Sonoita Creek Preserve. Located fireflies at three locations along Sonoita Creek.
occurrenceRemarks: 10 seen total at three separate locations along Sonoita Creek. All were flashing green. Saw one male fly down to a female (both were flashing) that was resting on vegetation. Flying about 3 feet above the ground prior to flying down to female. One was seen flying 4 m above the ground, which was much higher than the others. Some were in trees and some were on watercress in the creek.
habitatRemarks: Cottonwood, willow, ash, walnut, hackberry, elderberry
flashLocation: Some flying and flashing, some flashing from vegetation.
femaleFlashBehavior: Flashing from vegetation.

eventRemarks: Two locations with fireflies, the first is the location shown on the map and had at least 10 fireflies. The second location we only saw one.
occurrenceRemarks: Approximately 10 fireflies were flashing along the edge of the creek in some grass/wetland vegetation. They were all flying low, within a couple feet of the ground. They were all seen within a small area, approximately 20 -30 feet of creek bank. The other firefly was on wetland vegetation outside the riparian area and was flashing from the vegetation (not flying). No fireflies were seen in the cienega, or further downstream.
habitatRemarks: This area has riparian and cienega habitat. Fireflies were mostly seen right along the creek, but one was seen in an adjacent marshy area.
flashLocation: Flashing right along the edge of the creek. One was flashing from low wetland vegetation just outside the riparian trees.

eventRemarks: Approximately 35 individuals, including 2 SE of the road crossing
occurrenceRemarks: All directly along stream corridor
flashLocation: Along stream corridor

eventRemarks: Fireflies seen throughout the wetted stream length. Originally flying low early in the evening and flying >20 ft by 9pm. Forgot to measure temperature at start time so used end temperature for both start and end.
occurrenceRemarks: 12 mm in length for the male that was measured. Flying low early on, then flying well over 20 feet by 9pm.
habitatRemarks: Spring-fed stream with hot springs. Stays perennial for about 0.5 miles downstream of spring.
flashLocation: Still flashing when survey was ended at 9:06 pm. Temp only taken at the end of the survey.

eventRemarks: 49 fireflies counted. Some flying 20 feet or so above the ground. Most activity seen between 8 and 9pm.
occurrenceRemarks: 49 fireflies counted. Some flying 20 feet or so above the ground. Most activity seen between 8 and 9pm.
additionalObservers: Rowan Lynn, Yasmine Schafer, Terena Williams
habitatRemarks: Habitat included both cienega and riparian habitat along a stream.
flashLocation: Flashing from ground level to the tree tops. Seen in the riparian and fairly far (~50m) into the adjacent grassland/oak vegetation. Most fireflies seen flashing along the edge of the willows on the east side of the stream. No fireflies were seen in the cienega at the south end of the property, only along the stringer of riparian further north.

identificationRemarks: Narrow body, thick black stripe down center of pronotum with margins tinged in black, black scutellum. Triple flash.
occurrenceRemarks: At least 40 individuals documented. Highest concentrations surrounding piles of downed vegetation. Multiple males flashing on the ground as well as flying
habitatRemarks: Along Rincon Creek; standing water extending approximately 100m in either direction from site; densely vegetated ~30m buffer around riparian corridor
flashLocation: All within 30m of Rincon Creek.

eventRemarks: Fireflies spotted. Appeared to flash green, asynchronous of each other.
occurrenceRemarks:
body length approx 1.5cm - 2cm
stayed mostly near tall reeds along standing water
often settled on reeds that felt serrated/rough
fireflies did not seem to stay together as a group
flew between 1ft - 6ft off ground
habitatRemarks: along gulch with cottonwood trees
flashLocation: near reeds in standing water from recent rainfall

eventRemarks: Counted 5 fireflies flying above grassy field. Did not see any on the ground
locality: Patagonia-Sonoita Creek site 2 by Visitor Center
occurrenceRemarks: most flying about 2-3 meters above grass.
areaSearchedInHa: 4 hectare field, only counted fireflies with in 6 meters
habitatRemarks: Dominant species Johnson Grass, mullein; recently mowed
flashLocation: Above grass field
maleFlashBehavior: Noted mostly 2 sometimes 3 flashes in most of the fireflies seen. Flew a little higher each flash
femaleFlashBehavior: none observed

eventRemarks: Arrived to site at approx 6:30 to scout. Searched veg along creek at dusk but no firefly larvae or adults observed. Stopped by main pools on the way back down the drainage (10:59-11:10pm) but did not see any firefly activity.
occurrenceRemarks: Single adult male observed. Pronotum edged in black with thick black center stripe. Yellow elytral margins. Relatively slender body with length slightly over 8 mm.
habitatRemarks: Series of granite/basalt bedrock pools with perennial water. Large boulders. Primary riparian vegetation included Gooding's willow, oak (AZ white oak?), ash, sycamore, Eragrostis bunchgrasses, Indigofera, cattails. Upland vegetation on the hillsides composed of saguaros, ocotillos, feathertree.
flashLocation: flashing from edge of creek, very close to water surface. Flasher was very tied to that small area - did not venture far over the creek or to surrounding vegetation. When caught for ID, was perched on a Polygonum species (Persicaria?) growing in the water, near some cattails.
maleFlashBehavior: Mostly sedentary (non-flying) with no discernible flash pattern (sometimes single, sometimes 2-3 flashes). Very infrequent overall flashing over the course of the evening, with up to ten minutes or longer between flash activity.
femaleFlashBehavior: Not observed.

eventRemarks: A large monsoon system stalled over the site for approximately 30 minutes during our survey (after dark), dumping rain and illuminating the site with frequent intense lightning.
occurrenceRemarks: Approximately 4-5 individuals observed. One male and one female captured for verification, and then released. Male was 8mm in length with darkened pronotal margins, thick black center pronotal line, slender body (see photos). Near the end of the survey, at 10:20pm, there was a single mystery flasher that we were unable to capture. It gave off a single prolonged flash and the color appeared almost white-blue. It was flying high, streaking with its prolonged flash, before disappearing into the vegetation on the hillside.
habitatRemarks: Sandy bottomed grotto/amphitheater along Rincon Creek with ryholite walls and dominant riparian vegetation of Baccharis, buttonbush, ash, sycamore, walnut, Eragrostis bunchgrasses. Scattered Persicaria and primrose.
flashLocation: Flashing occurred primarily in the treetops (often over 8 ft high) and open spaces between the trees across the open grotto (near the downstream end of the creek).
maleFlashBehavior: Most male flash patterns were composed of just two flashes, although some emitted the typical three. The third flash was slightly less robust than the first two. After spotting the lone female, one of the males shortened his flash pattern as he homed in on her location, clustering flashes closer together, and also making them less bright.
femaleFlashBehavior: One female was observed (the first flash of the evening - she began flashing approximately one hour before the males began flashing). Single yellow-green flash while perched on a tree branch approximately 7 ft high off the ground.

eventRemarks: Area has received decent monsoon rain in recent days. A couple days prior to surveys, the creek level was flowing steadily, with no sand exposed.
occurrenceRemarks: At least a dozen fireflies observed over the course of the survey period. Two adult males were caught for species ID verification and measured 7.5 and 8 mm in length, each with yellow elytral margins, thick black center stripes on the pronotum, and black pronotal margins.
additionalObservers: Saff Killingsworth, Lucas Hetherington, Tony Palmer, Roni Doyon, Devon Stackonis, Melina Tye
habitatRemarks: Flat, open canopy sandy wash with standing water and scattered cobble/boulders. Dominant plants are grasses, catclaw acacia, oat grass, and Eragrostis bunchgrasses. There's a cluster of trees within the survey area providing shade that's composed of a sycamore and canyon hackberry.
flashLocation: Adult males seen cruising up and down the moist side channel along the creek bed, which is bordered by lush grass. They were flying high, typically 6 feet up to the upper branches of the sycamore and hackberry. Flashes were also observed in the more heavily forested hillside up towards the driveway to the house. Individuals seemed concentrated in the darker undercanopy by the trees.
maleFlashBehavior: Both double and triple flash patterns were observed. Males would fly parallel to the ground, rise, then slowly swoop down with slightly less vivid flashing. Several individuals were seen looping around the survey area, flying from the moist side channel up towards the trees, circling around these trees, swinging back out to the main creek channel, and then closing in to the side channel.
femaleFlashBehavior: Single flashes observed from low vegetation in the forested hillside by the driveway.

eventRemarks: Saw one Bicellonycha wickershamorum earlier in the evening, when Photinus knulli were just emerging. It flew up into a tree flashing only a few times in flight, and then rested in the tree, only occasionally flashing. The Microphotus was found on my shirt shortly after capturing a Photinus knulli and after bushwacking along the eastern edge of the riparian stringer, just south of the road. The flashing began at 7:50 from the ground/low vegetation within the riparian area. The BW was seen shortly after this and then not seen again later in the evening. A female firefly that had been captured by a spider was collected by the preserve manager and will be deposited in the UA insect collection. Cloud cover increased over the survey period from 0-20% up to 41-60%. GoPro footage was recorded within the riparian area starting at 9:45 PM and will be send to Owen to determine if enough flashes were recorded for the model to verify the species as PK.
occurrenceRemarks: BW was only seen for a short time and flew up into a tree while flashing. I was unable to capture it.
habitatRemarks: Cottonwood, walnut, willow, ash, hackberry overstory.
flashLocation: Flew from low vegetation into a tree. Flashed a few times while flying up into the tree, then only occasionally thereafter.
maleFlashBehavior: Flew from low vegetation into a tree. Flashed a few times while flying up into the tree, then only occasionally thereafter.

eventRemarks: Saw one Bicellonycha wickershamorum earlier in the evening, when Photinus knulli were just emerging. It flew up into a tree flashing only a few times in flight, and then rested in the tree, only occasionally flashing. The Microphotus was found on my shirt shortly after capturing a Photinus knulli and after bushwacking along the eastern edge of the riparian stringer, just south of the road. The flashing began at 7:50 from the ground/low vegetation within the riparian area. The BW was seen shortly after this and then not seen again later in the evening. A female firefly that had been captured by a spider was collected by the preserve manager and will be deposited in the UA insect collection. Cloud cover increased over the survey period from 0-20% up to 41-60%. GoPro footage was recorded within the riparian area starting at 9:45 PM and will be send to Owen to determine if enough flashes were recorded for the model to verify the species as PK.
occurrenceRemarks: ~8.2mm for the one measured with calipers. Three flash sequence with a pause in between. Were flashing within the riparian as well as along the edge within the low-lying upland vegetation/cobble.
habitatRemarks: Cottonwood, walnut, willow, ash, hackberry overstory.
flashLocation: Flashes started earlier in the night within the riparian on low vegetation and gradually moved higher and out of the riparian into adjacent habitats. Flashing was still occurring when survey ended so last flash is actually the survey end time.
maleFlashBehavior: Flashes started earlier in the night within the riparian on low vegetation and gradually moved higher and out of the riparian into adjacent habitats.
femaleFlashBehavior: Seen flashing from the ground or low vegetation.

occurrenceRemarks: Approximately 4 individuals observed.
habitatRemarks: Historic livestock waterer (established since at least the 1950s) centered on an old spring supported by a pump to supplement flow. Line of cottonwoods along southern exposure of the pond. Seep willow along bank, as well as tule (bulrush) and sedges. Pond is located in a small drainage.
flashLocation: Initially flashing from tule (bulrush) and right above the sedges lining the pond, then eventually moving higher above the vegetation and circling the pond, picking up speed with both flashing and movement. Active approximately 3-5 feet above ground.
maleFlashBehavior: Green single flash every one to three seconds, very variable. Activity period was rather short (only one individual still displaying at the end of the survey) with very few individuals.
femaleFlashBehavior: N/A

occurrenceRemarks: First firefly observed at 7:16pm on tip of grass blade adjacent to pond (not yet flashing). Others observed clinging to vegetation. Several were seen mouthing the feathery tips of Eleocharis palustris. Over 100 fireflies were observed on this night--possibly even up to 150.
habitatRemarks: Two small historic cattle ponds circled by bunchgrasses, sedges (Eleocharis palustris) and tule (bulrush). Open canopy with one seep willow. Ponds are groundwater/pump fed and have been there for at least the last 15 years.
flashLocation: Flashes in and just above vegetation (sedges, grasses, tree marigolds).
maleFlashBehavior: Flying very low, skimming the tops of the sedges, occasionally landing and slowly cruising between individual grass and sedge blades. Individual flashing males would move up and down the blades, pause, and then move to the next clump. By 7:52pm, they began moving higher to bulrushes. Activity was primarily adjacent to the ponds, although some were observed moving out 5-10 feet from the pond edges or drifting between the two ponds. First flash was seen at 7:30pm; by 7:41, approx. 24 individuals were seen flashing; by 7:52, more than 50 flashing, and by 8:02pm over 100 flashing.
femaleFlashBehavior: Single flashes low in vegetation.

eventRemarks: Arrived after surveying a different site, so caught only the tail end of the firefly activity period.
occurrenceRemarks: Approximately 4 individuals observed.
habitatRemarks: Small constructed pond (groundwater/pump-fed) surrounded by sedges in otherwise arid desert shrub environment.
flashLocation: Flashing along pond edges, above vegetation.
maleFlashBehavior: Rising up and down over the vegetation of the pond.

occurrenceRemarks: 15-20 individuals observed along the ponds and flying in between. At least one individual (see photo) did not have the characteristic yellow outlines on the elytral margins but was instead completely black.
habitatRemarks: Three large ponds surrounded by reeds, cattails, and yerba mensa. Each pond is circled by a double fence to keep out cattle, which were present in the fields all around the ponds.
flashLocation: Flashing just above shorter reeds and sedges along sides of ponds, and above vegetation between ponds, moving back and forth between them.
maleFlashBehavior: One pulse of green light as they slowly cruise around above the vegetation.
femaleFlashBehavior: One flash observed from vegetation.

eventRemarks: I was setting up mist nets for bats at Sparke's Spring, when I noticed the light of fireflies.
identificationRemarks: Phenology and morphology match Bicellonycha wickershamorum.
locality: Sparke's Spring at Coronado National Memorial
flashLocation: Observed flashes between 0-2 meters

eventRemarks:
7:53PM first flash. Flashing concentrated into shadows of trees due to bright moonlight.
Still, many individuals flashing at 9:55Pm when survey concluded.
locality: Tumacacori National Historical Park, Santa Cruz River
occurrenceRemarks:
6-10mm in length
males flashing from low grass to the highest parts of the canopy.
habitatRemarks:
Mesquite Bosque, Cottonwood-Willow forest, and Riparian areas surveyed.
Dominant Vegetation: Freemont's Cottonwood, Mesquite, Canyon Hackberry, Seep Willow, Ambrosia sp.
flashLocation:
Males flashing from low grass to the highest parts of the canopy (~24 meters).
Females flashing from grasses and low shrubs.
maleFlashBehavior:
1.5 second triplets with 6-8 seconds of pause in between triplets.
Wave and true synchrony events observed.
femaleFlashBehavior: muted single to triple flashes, and some sustained glows for 3-5 seconds.

eventRemarks: Temperatures were cool 67F at start and 61F at end of the survey. Moon was bright and flash period was very brief, 7:00 PM- 8:15PM.
locality: Tumacacori National Historical Park, Santa Cruz River
occurrenceRemarks: Males and females flashed between 7:00PM and 8:15PM. No flashes when temperature dropped below 63 degrees F.
habitatRemarks: Freemont's Cottonwood, Gooding's Willow, Mesquite, Johnsongrass.
flashLocation: In shaded areas under trees and bushes. Brief flight of males and then males retreated to the vegetation and continued flashing as temperatures dropped.
maleFlashBehavior: Males flying with the triplet flashes when temperatures were between 65 degrees F and 64 degrees F. When temperatures dropped below 64 degrees F, the males dropped into the vegetation and continued to flash with the triplets until temperatures dropped below 63 degrees F, when the flashing stopped.
femaleFlashBehavior: Sporadic glows or blinking from low vegetation. Flashes stopped at 63 degrees F.

eventRemarks: The area surveyed was a mosaic of warm and cool air pockets. Temperatures recorded during the survey fluctuated from 80F to 65F and these temperature variations of up to 15 degrees were often 1 meter or less apart. P. knulli tended to be most concentrated in the pockets of air that were above 70F. Little to no activity was recorded in areas where temperatures were in the mid 60's.
locality: Tumacacori National Historical Park, Santa Cruz River
occurrenceRemarks: 181 individuals observed during the survey in warm pockets of air in the shade of tall vegetation. Groups would shift with warm air pockets and cool air pockets would cause areas to stop flashing. The areas where cool air was replaced with warmer air would become active again.
habitatRemarks: Freemont's Cottonwood, Gooding's Willow, Mesquite, Johnsongrass.
flashLocation: In shaded areas under trees and bushes.
maleFlashBehavior: Males flying with the triplet flashes
femaleFlashBehavior: Sporadic glows or blinking from low vegetation.

eventRemarks: 76 individuals counted on the night
locality: Tumacacori National Historical Park, Santa Cruz River
habitatRemarks: Freemont's Cottonwood, Gooding's Willow, Mesquite, Johnsongrass.
flashLocation: In shaded areas under trees and bushes
maleFlashBehavior: Males flying with the triplet flashes, some males observed flashing from vegetation did not take flight during the time they were being observed.
femaleFlashBehavior: Sporadic glows or blinking from low vegetation.

occurrenceRemarks: 11mm in length, flashing sporadically. A couple flashing over the creek and a couple adjacent to the creek.
habitatRemarks: Cottonwood, walnut, hackberry
flashLocation: Flashing just above the creek or adjacent to it.

additionalObservers: Joe Cicero, Elizabeth Hamilton, Kathy West, Amber Anderson
flashLocation: Primarily flashing from veg early in the evening, then while flying, then from the ground later in the night.

eventRemarks: Monsoon came in so survey was ended early. Fireflies were still seen flying, even in a downpour.
additionalObservers: Claire Bunch, Gita Bodner, Brittany Garza
habitatRemarks: Surveyed within riparian, mesquite bosque, and cienega
flashLocation: Flashing primarily within the riparian area or along the edge of the riparian area. Also seen in the cienega.

additionalObservers: Candace Fallon, Terena Williams, Rowan Lynn, Yasmine Schafer
habitatRemarks: Surveyed within cienega and riparian areas
flashLocation: Flashing primarily within riparian area

eventRemarks: Ended survey early due to lightning
additionalObservers: Rowan Lynn, Terena Williams, Yasmine Schafer, Ellie Bernett
habitatRemarks: Surveyed riparian, woodland, and cienega
flashLocation: Flashing within riparian and cienega areas

eventRemarks: Surveyed on private land with landowner and biologist from Partners for Fish and Wildlife. Fireflies were only seen in areas with water, despite promising-looking habitat in intermittent reaches. Land is adjacent to BLM, SPRNCA, and neighbors on both sides of this landowner allowed us access as well.
occurrenceRemarks: Only found where the pond is and downstream where there is standing water.
additionalObservers: Rowan Lynn, Yasmine Schafer, Terena Williams, Joe Cicero, Sarah Gandaria
habitatRemarks: Along the Babocomari River.
flashLocation: Flashing near pond and areas with standing water

locality: Tumacacori National Historical Park, Santa Cruz River
occurrenceRemarks: Still small groups of males and stray females active by the Santa Cruz River. 17 individuals observed during survey.
habitatRemarks: Fremont’s cottonwood,  Mesquite, Johnsongrass, Ambrosia and common sunflower.
flashLocation: In the tall weeds and just below the canopies of the cottonwoods
maleFlashBehavior:
Males flashing triplets  from low grass to the lowest parts of the canopy (~24 meters). Females flashing from grasses and low shrubs.
• fireflyatlas.org
femaleFlashBehavior: Sporadic flashes and glows from low in the vegetation.
